thread.title: How these Mets remind Ron Darling of 1986 champs
thread.title_full: How these Mets remind Ron Darling of 1986 champs | New York Post

author: Justin Terranova
title: How these Mets remind Ron Darling of 1986 champs
text:
The Mets connection to 1986 can be seen from third-base coach Tim Teufel to Triple-A manager Wally Backman to the broadcast booth where Ron Darling and Keith Hernandez reside next to Gary Cohen.
The temptation is to compare the growth of these Mets to their Mets, a team that grew from the depths of the NL East in 1983 to contenders in ’84 and ’85 to champions in ‘86.
“What I do know is those teams were getting better and performing better and I feel the same way about this ball club, too,” said Darling, who will be in the TBS booth for the Mets’ postseason return, which comes Friday night against the Dodgers.
“Not only do they have wonderful pitching, as we did, but we added Keith Hernandez and Gary Carter and they’ve added Yoenis Cespedes and Michael Conforto. It reminds me of that. It’s all starting to come together. It’s not only the pitching, but people who can produce runs, catch the ball. When you start to put that all together, that’s when you have a team over 162 games that is primed and ready to go. The playoffs, you just don’t know, because it’s all the best teams at their best. So, they are going to have to turn it up a notch.”
The addition of Gary Carter helped the Mets get over the hump. Photo: AP The jump to 90 wins, as many as the second-place ’84 Mets had, was good enough for an NL East crown and it has set up highly anticipated pitching matchups in Los Angeles with Jacob deGrom facing Clayton Kershaw and Noah Syndergaard going up against Zack Greinke.
But it could be the Mets lineup that dictates just how far this October run will go.
“If they play like they did in August, the Mets will go deep in this thing,” Darling said. “I know that included Cespedes being red-hot, but that’s how you got to do it. It’s so tough to get through the playoffs now.”
Fellow TBS analyst and World Series champion Pedro Martinez agrees that the Mets are a “dangerous team.” Martinez pointed to the importance of Steven Matz pitching in the series to get out the
Dodgers big lefty bats and a curiosity to seeing the 22-year-old Syndergaard on the playoff stage.
Noah Syndergaard Photo: Ray Stubblebine “Syndergaard is a kid that is going to be a bulldog, a big horse in the future. He’s the youngest one, but his demeanor on the mound is impressive,” Martinez said. “I can’t wait to see him in the future. He has the mental toughness and approach of a big-time pitcher. If he does it now it would be surprising, but I expect him to be better in a few years. Anything he accomplishes here would be over-achieving.”
The decision to pitch Syndergaard in Game 2 on the road — where he has been significantly less effective than he’s been at Citi Field — pushed Matt Harvey to Game 3. The controversial righty angered captain David Wright when he missed Tuesday’s workout.
“The issue for [Harvey] is this is a really hard game to pitch without a target on your back,” Darling said. “And Game 3 is always the most important, you’re down by two you’re saving the season, you’re up two you can take your team to NLCS, if you’re 1-1 it becomes the pivotal game of the series. If Matt throws nine shutout innings, do you think anyone is going to care?”
  los angeles dodgers ,  matt harvey ,  mlb playoffs ,  new york mets ,  noah syndergaard ,  ron darling
